Exception messages in Get-ChildItem are inconsistent, and sometimes incorrect, depending on whether the given -Path has a backslash at the end and whether the -Recurse switch is added.

# Steps to reproduce
In this example, the path `C:\Users\Foo` does not exist. The directory I am running PowerShell from is `C:\Users\[username]`.

Example 1: -Path with no trailing backslash, no -Recurse
```powershell
Get-ChildItem -Path 'C:\Users\Foo'
```
Example 2: -Path with trailing backslash, no -Recurse
```powershell
Get-ChildItem -Path 'C:\Users\Foo\'
```
Example 3: Path with no trailing backslash, -Recurse 
```powershell
Get-ChildItem -Path 'C:\Users\Foo' -Recurse
```
Example 4: Path with trailing backslash, -Recurse
```powershell
Get-ChildItem -Path 'C:\Users\Foo\' -Recurse
```
# Expected behavior
Ideally, all of these would have the same exception thrown. 

# Actual behavior
Example 1: -Path with no trailing backslash, no -Recurse
```powershell
Get-ChildItem : Cannot find path 'C:\Users\Foo' because it does not exist.
At line:1 char:1
+ Get-ChildItem -path 'C:\Users\Foo'
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
+ CategoryInfo          : ObjectNotFound: (C:\Users\Foo:String) [Get-ChildItem], ItemNotFoundException
+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : PathNotFound,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetChildItemCommand
```
Example 2: -Path with trailing backslash, no -Recurse
```powershell
Get-ChildItem : Cannot find path 'C:\Users\Foo\' because it does not exist.
At line:1 char:1
+ Get-ChildItem -path 'C:\Users\Foo\'
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
+ CategoryInfo          : ObjectNotFound: (C:\Users\Foo\:String) [Get-ChildItem], ItemNotFoundException
+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : PathNotFound,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetChildItemCommand
```
Example 3: Path with no trailing backslash, -Recurse 

- No error message regarding the given path is thrown. The cmdlet appears to try to search `C:\Users\`, as there are `UnauthorizedAccessExceptions` for something I have in `C:\Users\Public` if I do not run PowerShell as administrator. 

Example 4: Path with trailing backslash, -Recurse
```powershell
Get-ChildItem : Cannot find path 'C:\Users\F' because it does not exist.
At line:1 char:1
+ Get-ChildItem -path 'C:\Users\Foo\' -recurse
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
+ CategoryInfo          : ObjectNotFound: (C:\Users\F:String) [Get-ChildItem], ItemNotFoundException
+ FullyQualifiedErrorId : PathNotFound,Microsoft.PowerShell.Commands.GetChildItemCommand
```
This message occurs even if the path `C:\Users\F` exists, which can make it misleading in some cases.

# Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->
This error occurs both in PS6 and PS7. 
```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.2.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    6.2.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.18932
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

```powershell

----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.0-preview.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.0-preview.1

````
